dialog.text: Why are the rules so strict? It's not fair—you're making everything harder for me.
Rules look strict because they hold a shape for learning. But when you say 'it's unfair,' I hear something deeper.
Deeper what? You're the one who punishes. I don't like you because you take my choices away.
I am your teacher and your shadow at once. I show the limits you avoid—those parts that call rules 'punishment.'
So... you're saying it's not the rules that are the problem, it's me?
Often yes. 'Life is unfair' is a convenient story that hands your power away. Blame points outward so you don't look inside.
How do I stop blaming everything? I don't want to feel controlled all the time.
Begin with one honest sentence to yourself. Name the feeling and the need beneath it—slowly. For example: 'I feel angry because I want more choice.'
I... I feel angry because I want freedom.
Good. Now ask: 'What in me resists this freedom?' Curiosity softens blame into something you can work with.
Maybe I'm afraid I'll mess up if I'm totally free. If I had full choice, I'd fail and everyone would see me fail.
There—there's the wound. Rules became a mirror and a guard for that scared part. Thank that part; it tried to keep you safe.
I never thought of rules as protection. I thought they were the enemy keeping me small.
dialog.instructions: softening, reflective, a hint of relief

dialog.text: When your story shifts from 'life is unfair' to 'what am I afraid of?' the shadow and the boy can become allies.
So my resistance softened when I spoke honestly. That feels different—possible.
Yes. The inner work is tiny admissions like this repeated. Responsibility is not punishment—it's freedom in disguise.
Pause now. Notice one place you blame the outside for how you feel; say one honest sentence to yourself about it, then share that sentence in the comments—let's turn blame into curiosity together.
